oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dragonfly Decorated Automobile
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard of 1908 Oldsmobile Model M Palace Touring Car decorated with dragonflies and daisies with four occupants. It is believed that the automobile was part of the 1924 revival of the Floral Fete parade in Saratoga Springs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1901 Floral Fete Broadside
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A souvenir broadside announcing the Grand Fete Day and Eighth Annual Floral Parade and Festival (a.k.a. Floral Fete) in 1901 in Saratoga Springs. The broadside states that "Rex, King of the Carnival of Mardi Gras of New Orleans, will this year join us in our festivities. He comes with a royal retinue and following of over one hundred loyal subjects, lords and their ladies, costumed richly as becoming their stations, occupying twenty magnificently decorated floats, drawn by over one hundred horses and attended by hundreds of the king's royal household."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Penfield, Charles P.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parades
Broadsides
Rex, King of the Carnival of Mardi Gras
Community & Events
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Saratoga Springs - Saratoga County - New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: broadside; 14 x 8 1/2 in. (35.56 x 21.59 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational uses. Please cite as Saratoga Room, Saratoga Springs Public Library . Prior written permission is required for any other use of the images.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1901 Music Float
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of music float from 1901 Floral Fete parade. Description from souvenir program reads: "A huge harp occupies nearly all the available space in this striking float. Garlands depend from every part of this enormous instrument, and two maskers, garbed in Greek robes, exert themselves to evoke harmonious sounds from the giant strings. In the front of the car an extraordinary plant grows, the leaves of which are in the form of violins and the blossoms in the form of trumpets. A slightly elevated compartment in the rear of the car is surrounded by a low parapet embellished with a bar of music and contains a group of musicians. A canopy shelters them from the sun."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McDowall, John, 1844-1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parades; Mardi Gras (festival)
Parades & processions

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Spencer Trask in Carriage at Yaddo
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Spencer Trask, investment banker and philanthropist, was president of the Saratoga Floral Association from 1900-1901. Here he is pictured in his carriage decorated in princess pine and ostrich feathers in the driveway of his Saratoga home, Yaddo. His wife, Katrina, is seen in the upper righthand of the photo, looking out of a second story window of their mansion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Carriages and carts

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1898 Official Program Floral Fete Saratoga
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Peace and Victory" was the theme of the 1898 Floral Fete, the year of the Spanish American War. The theme of the Floral Association's float was "Star Spangled Banner". The program lists the participants in the Bicycle Division, Bicycle Floats, Division of Decorated Carriages, and the Float Division. The black and white cover photograph is of a decorated horsedrawn carriage on the parade route. The cover image also uses two historic engravings of Saratoga Springs including an illustration of a Native American family at High Rock Spring which was used in the official seal of the City of Saratoga Springs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Saratoga Floral Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parades

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1899 Floral Peace Jubilee and Carnival
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This cover for the souvenir program for the Saratoga Floral Association's Carnival and Floral Parade and Ball features women in classical costume. The figure on the left with butterfly wings appears to be Psyche, the Greek goddess of the soul. The figure on the right, wearing a helmet and holding a shield, may be Athena, the Greek goddess of war. Doves and floral images also are seen on the cover.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Saratoga Floral Association

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Fairy Turnout
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Floral Fete parades included floats, bicycles, and various types of carriages decorated in flowers. This stereoview image shows a young boy in his floral decorated cart pulled by two goats. His entry number is 31. Part of a decorated bicycle can be seen in the background.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1924 Revival of the Floral Fete
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Floral Fete was revived in 1924. It was a one day event with the floral parade in the afternoon and a floral ball in the evening. The parade was led by the 105th Infantry Band, then the saddle horse division which consisted of local citizens dressed as historic characters. They were followed by horse drawn floats, the bicycle division, an automobile division, and motor driven floats. Each division was preceeded by a marching band. The cover of the program describes Saratoga Springs as "The peerless summer winter and health resort of America in the foothills of the Adirondacks". The image on the cover shows a team of black horses pulling a carriage with occupants following a small black and white dog. In the background are buildings in Franklin Square.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parades

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Library Birthday Celebration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Saratoga Springs Public Library marked its first birthday at a program at the library. Margaret Glasby, first library director, holds the John Cotton Dana Award, Percy W. Dake, chairman of the building committee, holds the cake, and Dr. H. Dunham Hunt holds a citation presented to him for "his outstanding contribution in the promotion and construction of the Saratoga Springs Public Library".

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Professor Nathan Sheppard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of Nathan Sheppard who was the founder and first president of the Saratoga Athenaeum. Sheppard was a lecturer on Modern English and rhetoric at the University of Chicago at the time the photograph was taken. He compiled and edited numerous works including "Saratoga Chips and Carlsbad Wafers" (1887).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fassett, S. M. (Samuel Montague), 1825-1910
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Authors, American;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Saratoga Athenaeum Sign
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Saratoga Athenaeum was incorporated in 1885. According to its constitution and by-laws, "[t]he object of this corporation shall be to furnish Saratoga Springs with a Public Circulating and Reference Library, a Public Reading Room, a Lectureship and a School of Design." Membership was by paid subscription. The first location of the Athenaeum was at 440 Broadway, on the corner of Broadway and Caroline Street.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Saratoga Athenaeum

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1896 Saratoga Floral Parade and Battle of Flowers Program
1897 Saratoga Floral Parade and Battle of Flowers Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Program for the Fourth Annual Parade, Battle of Flowers and Floral Ball which took place on 7 September 1897. The booklet includes photographs of scenes in Saratoga Springs, a description of the planned events, and a list of the persons involved with planning the events. The honorary president was Franklin W. Smith, a Bostonian whose visions inspired the floral parades.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Saratoga Floral Festival Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parades

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1895 Literary and Floral Fete Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1895, a literary and history conference was held as part of the Floral Fete. Prominent authors and writers were listed as patrons of the event. They included Samuel Clemens, Julia Ward Howe, Sarah Orne Jewett, and Katrina Trask. Authors' readings were held at the Opera House in the morning of September 3rd. In the evening, "representations of Roman life and historical incidents, in life and action" were held in the Pompeian House of Pansa. September 4th was "Historical Day" with "a celebration of American Historical Events" taking place at the Saratoga Opera House in the morning and in the evening a celebration of the life of Benjamin Franklin was held at Convention Hall. The event was planned as an annual festival but no documentation has been found to indicate that this occured.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Smith, Franklin Webster, 1825-1911
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Congresses and conventions

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1901 Souvenir Program Rex Pageant
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Souvenir booklet containing images of floats and descriptions of each themed float participating in the Eighth Annual Floral Parade and Carnival in Saratoga Springs. The Saratoga Floral Association purchased the entire Rex Parade from the New Orleans Mardi Gras in February, 1901, and shipped the floats and costumes to Saratoga Springs for the annual floral fete parade which took place on September 5, 1901.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Saratoga Floral Association
